trans-unit.source: What is Blob Storage
trans-unit.target: What is Blob Storage

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob storage is a service for storing large amounts of
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob storage is a service for storing large amounts of

trans-unit.source: unstructured data, such as text or binary data, that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via
trans-unit.target: unstructured data, such as text or binary data, that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via

trans-unit.source: HTTP or HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: HTTP or HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: You can use Blob storage to expose data publicly to the world, or
trans-unit.target: You can use Blob storage to expose data publicly to the world, or

trans-unit.source: to store application data privately.
trans-unit.target: to store application data privately.

trans-unit.source: Common uses of Blob storage include:
trans-unit.target: Common uses of Blob storage include:

trans-unit.source: Serving images or documents directly to a browser
trans-unit.target: Serving images or documents directly to a browser

trans-unit.source: Storing files for distributed access
trans-unit.target: Storing files for distributed access

trans-unit.source: Streaming video and audio
trans-unit.target: Streaming video and audio

trans-unit.source: Performing secure backup and disaster recovery
trans-unit.target: Performing secure backup and disaster recovery

trans-unit.source: Storing data for analysis by an on-premises or Azure-hosted service
trans-unit.target: Storing data for analysis by an on-premises or Azure-hosted service

trans-unit.source: Blob service concepts
trans-unit.target: Blob service concepts

trans-unit.source: The Blob service contains the following components:
trans-unit.target: The Blob service contains the following components:

trans-unit.source: Blob1
trans-unit.target: Blob1

trans-unit.source: **Storage Account:** All access to Azure Storage is done
trans-unit.target: **Storage Account:** All access to Azure Storage is done

trans-unit.source: through a storage account.
trans-unit.target: through a storage account.

trans-unit.source: See [Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets](storage-scalability-targets.md) for details about storage account capacity.
trans-unit.target: See [Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets](storage-scalability-targets.md) for details about storage account capacity.

trans-unit.source: **Container:** A container provides a grouping of a set of blobs.
trans-unit.target: **Container:** A container provides a grouping of a set of blobs.

trans-unit.source: All blobs must be in a container.
trans-unit.target: All blobs must be in a container.

trans-unit.source: An account can contain an
trans-unit.target: An account can contain an

trans-unit.source: unlimited number of containers.
trans-unit.target: unlimited number of containers.

trans-unit.source: A container can store an unlimited
trans-unit.target: A container can store an unlimited

trans-unit.source: number of blobs.
trans-unit.target: number of blobs.

trans-unit.source: **Blob:** A file of any type and size.
trans-unit.target: **Blob:** A file of any type and size.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage offers three types of blobs: block blobs, page blobs, and append blobs.
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage offers three types of blobs: block blobs, page blobs, and append blobs.

trans-unit.source: *Block blobs* are ideal for storing text or binary files, such as documents and media files.
trans-unit.target: *Block blobs* are ideal for storing text or binary files, such as documents and media files.

trans-unit.source: *Append blobs* are similar to block blobs in that they are made up of blocks, but they are optimized for append operations, so they are useful for logging scenarios.
trans-unit.target: *Append blobs* are similar to block blobs in that they are made up of blocks, but they are optimized for append operations, so they are useful for logging scenarios.

trans-unit.source: A single block blob or append blob can contain up to 50,000 blocks of up to 4 MB each, for a total size of slightly more than 195 GB (4 MB X 50,000).
trans-unit.target: A single block blob or append blob can contain up to 50,000 blocks of up to 4 MB each, for a total size of slightly more than 195 GB (4 MB X 50,000).

trans-unit.source: *Page blobs* can be up to 1 TB in size, and are more efficient for frequent read/write operations.
trans-unit.target: *Page blobs* can be up to 1 TB in size, and are more efficient for frequent read/write operations.

trans-unit.source: Azure Virtual Machines use page blobs as OS and data disks.
trans-unit.target: Azure Virtual Machines use page blobs as OS and data disks.

trans-unit.source: For more information about blobs, see [Understanding Block Blobs, Page Blobs, and Append Blobs](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee691964.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about blobs, see [Understanding Block Blobs, Page Blobs, and Append Blobs](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee691964.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Naming and referencing containers and blobs
trans-unit.target: Naming and referencing containers and blobs

trans-unit.source: You can address a blob in your storage account using the following URL format:
trans-unit.target: You can address a blob in your storage account using the following URL format:

trans-unit.source: For example, here is a URL that addresses one of the blobs in the diagram above:
trans-unit.target: For example, here is a URL that addresses one of the blobs in the diagram above:

trans-unit.source: Container naming rules
trans-unit.target: Container naming rules

trans-unit.source: A container name must be a valid DNS name and conform to the following rules:
trans-unit.target: A container name must be a valid DNS name and conform to the following rules:

trans-unit.source: A container name must be all lowercase.
trans-unit.target: A container name must be all lowercase.

trans-unit.source: Container names must start with a letter or number, and can contain only letters, numbers, and the dash (-) character.
trans-unit.target: Container names must start with a letter or number, and can contain only letters, numbers, and the dash (-) character.

trans-unit.source: Every dash (-) character must be immediately preceded and followed by a letter or number; consecutive dashes are not permitted in container names.
trans-unit.target: Every dash (-) character must be immediately preceded and followed by a letter or number; consecutive dashes are not permitted in container names.

trans-unit.source: Container names must be from 3 through 63 characters long.
trans-unit.target: Container names must be from 3 through 63 characters long.

trans-unit.source: Blob naming rules
trans-unit.target: Blob naming rules

trans-unit.source: A blob name must conform to the following rules:
trans-unit.target: A blob name must conform to the following rules:

trans-unit.source: A blob name can contain any combination of characters.
trans-unit.target: A blob name can contain any combination of characters.

trans-unit.source: A blob name must be at least one character long and cannot be more than 1,024 characters long.
trans-unit.target: A blob name must be at least one character long and cannot be more than 1,024 characters long.

trans-unit.source: Blob names are case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: Blob names are case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: Reserved URL characters must be properly escaped.
trans-unit.target: Reserved URL characters must be properly escaped.

trans-unit.source: The number of path segments comprising the blob name cannot exceed 254.
trans-unit.target: The number of path segments comprising the blob name cannot exceed 254.

trans-unit.source: A path segment is the string between consecutive delimiter characters (*e.g.*, the forward slash '/') that corresponds to the name of a virtual directory.
trans-unit.target: A path segment is the string between consecutive delimiter characters (*e.g.*, the forward slash '/') that corresponds to the name of a virtual directory.

trans-unit.source: The Blob service is based on a flat storage scheme.
trans-unit.target: The Blob service is based on a flat storage scheme.

trans-unit.source: You can create a virtual hierarchy by specifying a character or string delimiter within the blob name to create a virtual hierarchy.
trans-unit.target: You can create a virtual hierarchy by specifying a character or string delimiter within the blob name to create a virtual hierarchy.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following list shows some valid and unique blob names:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following list shows some valid and unique blob names:

trans-unit.source: You can use the delimiter character to list blobs hierarchically.
trans-unit.target: You can use the delimiter character to list blobs hierarchically.
